sen.j: 徒士（かち）は、徒歩で戦う下級武士のことをいう。
sen.e: The term Kachi means lower class warriors who fought on foot.

sen.j: 近代軍制でいうと、馬上の資格がある侍（馬廻以上）が士官に相当し、徒士は下士官に相当する。
sen.e: According to the modern military system, warriors who are allowed to fight on horseback (Umamawari and above) correspond to officers and Kachi correspond to noncommissioned officers.

sen.j: 徒士は士分に含まれ、士分格を持たない足軽とは峻別される。
sen.e: Kachi were categorized into shibun (soldiers who had the status of samurai) and strictly distinguished from ashigaru (common warriors) who had not the status of samurai.

sen.j: 戦場では主君の前駆をなし、平時は城内の護衛（徒士組）や中間管理職的な行政職（目付、勘定奉行の配下など）に従事した。
sen.e: At the battle field, they fought as the forerunners of their lords and in peaceful time, they served as the guards (Kachi-gumi (Kachi teams) of castle or engaged in administrative jobs (metsuke (police) or subordinates of kanjo-bugyo (commissioner of finance) as middle class managers.

sen.j: 江戸幕府における徒歩組（かちぐみ）は、徳川家康が慶長8年（1603年）に9組をもって成立した。
sen.e: Ieyasu TOKUGAWA established 9 Kachi-gumi (Kachi team) in 1603 as the organization of Edo bakufu.

sen.j: 幕府安定期には20組が徒歩頭の下にあり、各組毎に2人の組頭が、その下に各組28人の徒歩衆がいた。
sen.e: During the period when bakufu was stable, there were 20 Kachi teams under Kachigashira (superintendant of Kachi teams) and each team had 2 kumigashira (head of Kachi team) and 28 Kachi.

sen.j: 徒歩衆は、蔵米の御家人で、俸禄は70俵5人扶持。
sen.e: Kachi were gokenin (immediate vassals of shogun) who were entitled to kuramai (rice preserved in the depository of bakufu) and their salaly was 70 bales, the equivalent of five-men annual rice stipend.

sen.j: 礼服は熨斗目・白帷子、平服は黒縮緬の羽織・無紋の袴。
sen.e: Their formal suit was noshime (a kind of kimono)/shiro-katabira (light white hemp garment) and their normal suit was black crepe haori (Japanese half-coat)/hakama (pleated trousers) with no family crest.

sen.e: Their family status was initially gokenin (kakaezeki (the lowest rank of gokenin)), but it became fudai (the highest rank of gokenin) in 1862.
